Irish: Tá mé ag dul go Leitir Ceanainn.
Tá mé ag dul go dtí an garáiste.
Tá muid ag dul go dtí an garáiste.
Tá mé ag dul go dtí an t-ionad spóirt.
English: I'm going to the sports centre.

Irish: Tá mé ag dul go dtí an t-ionad siopadóireachta.
English: I'm going to the shopping centre.

Irish: Tá mé ag dul go dtí an t-ollmhargadh.
Tá mé ag dul go dtí an bhialann.
Tá mé ag dul go hoifig an phoist.
English: I am going to the post ofice

Irish: Tá mé ag dul go teach an phobail.
English: I am going to the church

Irish: tá mé ag dul a chodladh

Info: as in I'm going to ... and then I'm going to...

English: *Go doesn't affect words that begin with a consonant, but if the name begins with a vowel, h is placed before it.
Go dtí is used before nouns that are preceded by the article:

Irish: Tá mé ag dul go dtí an t-ospidéal.
English: I am going to the hospital.
The word chuig is used instead of go or go dtí when you're talking about going to an event or to see a person. We'll deal with chuig in more detail in Aonad 11.

Irish: Cad é an t-am atá tú ag dul go Dún Geanainn?
English: What time are you going to Dungannon?

Irish: Cá huair atá tú ag dul go Corcaigh?
English: When are you going to Cork?

Irish: Tá mé ag dul go Gaillimh...

English: The word uair is irregular when preceded by numbers:
This word occurs quite frequently in everyday speech, so it is well worth learning the different forms.
SAYING IT'S ALMOST A CERTAIN TIME

Irish: Tá sé chóir a bheith a dó a chlog.
Tá sé chóir a bheith a seacht.
Tá sé chóir a bheith leath i ndiaidh a haon.
Tá sé leath i ndiaidh a haon.
Tá sé ceathrú go dtí a dó dhéag
Tá sé ceathrú i ndiaidh a cúig
Phonetic: tay shay ca-ru i nyay a quig

Info: as in "scrúdú ar maidin" == "exam in the morning"
